long_desc.thetext:
Hello!
I am evaluating an upgrade from our cyrus 2.0.15 (patched) server to a cyrus 2.2.x murder setup. I am now trying to test moving mailboxes from the old system to the new by creating 'user.skitta' and then dropping the old mailbox on top of the new. Then I try 'reconstruct -r -f user.skitta' to add the mailboxes to the database.
Now, I might have a configuration problem which however triggers a bug which crashes reconstruct (segmentation fault). The problem is in mupdate-client.c in the function mupdate_connect(). Cyrus version is 2.2.3 in a murder setup, running on RedHat Linux 7.3. SASL 2.1.17, berkeley db-4.2.52-2.
- if any problems arise, the function bails out via a 'goto noconn;' - at 'noconn:' an entry is made to the log, at line 257, containing the value in h->pin. However, the jump can be made before h->pin is allocated (line 204). - thus, the syslog() call causes an segfault.
In my setup, it seems that sasl_client_new() (line 199) fails (most probably my fault), and the above happens. The same could happen if any of the "set the ip-addresses" or sasl-initialisation functions fail.
I propose this fix: line 257
- syslog(LOG_ERR, "mupdate-client: connection to server closed: %s", - prot_error(h->pin)); + if ( (h != NULL) && (h->pin != NULL) ) { + syslog(LOG_ERR, "mupdate-client: connection to server closed: %s", + prot_error(h->pin)); + } + else { + syslog(LOG_ERR, "mupdate-client: connection to server closed:"); + }
A call to fatal() could of course be another course of action.
regards,
/skitta UNIX systems administrator, Åbo Akademi University, Finland skitta@abo.fi
already fixed in cvs (revision 1.41 of mupdate-client.c)
